content.title: Essential Lighting Requirements for Crested Geckos
content.content: Crested geckos are crepuscular (most active at dawn and dusk) with exceptional night vision adapted for low-light conditions. UVB is optional for crested geckos because quality diets include vitamin D3, but low-level UVB can be beneficial. This guide covers lighting practices so you can choose what fits your setup.

Crested geckos receive filtered, indirect UVB in their natural cloud forest habitat. They are classified as Ferguson Zone 2, meaning they do best with low-level UVB exposure if you choose to provide it.

content.text: UVB Requirements:

rows: Allows self-regulation - gecko can choose UVB or shade

content.content: UVB is not strictly required if using vitamin D3-fortified crested gecko diet, BUT geckos with UVB access show improved appetite, natural behaviors, bone density, and immune function. Consider UVB a "best practice" rather than "survival minimum."
Low-output linear fluorescent UVB bulbs are ideal for crested geckos. Avoid high-output desert bulbs (10.0/12%) which provide excessive UVB.

content.text: Recommended UVB Bulbs (18x18x24 enclosure):

content.content: Do NOT use: compact/coil UVB bulbs (uneven UVB distribution, eye damage risk), mercury vapor bulbs (too intense for crested geckos), or "desert" strength bulbs (10.0/12%+ UVB causes stress and potential eye issues).
UVB intensity follows the inverse square law, doubling the distance quarters the UVB received. Proper placement ensures safe, effective exposure.

content.text: Mounting Distance Guidelines:

content.content: Verification is critical: Use a Solarmeter 6.5 to measure UVI at your perch after setup. Aim for 0.5-1.0 UVI. Adjust perch distance up or down to achieve target range. Mesh screens block 25-35% of UVB, so factor this into placement.
Beyond UVB, crested geckos benefit from visible light that supports circadian rhythms, enhances colors, and supports live plant growth.

content.text: Full-Spectrum Lighting Options:

rows: Full enclosure length, supports live plants
Excellent for bioactive, intense PAR for plant growth
Provides both visible light and basking heat
Premium option, simulates rainforest canopy light

content.content: UVB bulbs produce visible light but it's often dim. Pairing UVB with a separate 6500K LED or white heat lamp creates a more naturalistic photoperiod and better viewing for you.
Consistent day/night cycles regulate crested gecko activity patterns, feeding behavior, and overall health. Use timers to automate lighting schedules.

content.text: Lighting Schedule:

rows: Peak activity, breeding season, maximum feeding
Natural rest period, optional (not required for crested geckos)
Melatonin production, natural activity peak, hunting behavior

content.content: Use digital timers (one for heat lamp, one for UVB/LED lights). Set UVB to turn on at 7-8 AM and off at 7-8 PM for consistent 12-hour photoperiod. Heat lamp should turn off at night to allow temperature drop to 65-72F.
Crested geckos have tetrachromatic vision (see more colors than humans) and are sensitive to blue light wavelengths. Lighting affects their behavior and wellbeing.

content.text: Light Color Impact on Behavior:

rows: Natural activity rhythm, supports plant growth, enhances coloration
Calming, pairs well with basking heat, less intense
AVOID, suppresses melatonin, disrupts sleep, causes stress
AVOID, Better than blue but still disturbs natural darkness
IDEAL for nighttime, crested geckos have excellent night vision, don't need light

content.content: Do NOT use "moonlight" or blue LEDs at night. These disrupt natural melatonin production and stress crepuscular/nocturnal species. If you want to observe your gecko at night, use dim red light for 10-15 minutes max, then turn it off.
UVB output degrades over time even though the bulb still produces visible light. Replace bulbs on schedule to maintain effective UVB levels.

content.text: Bulb Replacement Schedule:

rows: Slower degradation due to better phosphor coating
Gradual dimming, no UVB so replacement less critical
Stops working entirely rather than degrading

content.content: Mark replacement dates on your calendar or use a label maker to note install date on the bulb. UVB bulbs often look fine visually but have lost 40-50% of their UVB output after 6-9 months (T8) or 12 months (T5).

content.text: Common Mistakes and Solutions:

rows: Uneven UVB distribution, potential eye damage
Switch to linear T8/T5 bulbs that spread UVB evenly
UVB bulb too close (<4" from gecko)
UVB overexposure, eye irritation, skin issues
Maintain 6-10" distance, measure UVI with Solarmeter
Glass or plastic between UVB and gecko
Ensure only mesh screen between bulb and gecko
Use timers for consistent 12-hour light/dark cycle
Complete darkness at night - no LEDs or viewing lights
Not replacing UVB bulbs on schedule
Gecko receives little/no UVB despite bulb still lighting
Replace T8 every 6-8 months, T5 every 12 months

content.content: Crested gecko care has evolved regarding UVB. Historically, many keepers avoided UVB entirely, relying on dietary vitamin D3. Modern research supports UVB provision.

content.text: UVB vs D3 Supplementation Comparison:

rows: Synthesized in skin from UVB exposure
Pre-formed D3 in crested gecko diet powder
Fixed dose, risk of over/under supplementation
Dietary D3 processed by liver (less efficient)
Improved appetite, bone density, activity levels
Adequate for survival, but some deficiencies seen long-term
No additional cost (D3 already in CGD)

content.content: If budget allows, low-level UVB can be a quality-of-life upgrade. If you skip UVB, a high-quality CGD with D3 is still an acceptable baseline. If you use UVB, keep it low (0.5-1.0 UVI).

content.text: Essential Lighting Equipment:

rows: 12" Zoo Med ReptiSun 5.0 T8 OR Arcadia 6% T8
Low-level UVB for vitamin D3 synthesis
Houses UVB bulb, reflector increases efficiency by 30-50%
Enhances plant growth in bioactive, bright viewing
Verify UVB levels at basking area (target 1.0-2.0)

content.content: Initial investment: $60-100 for lighting setup (UVB bulb, fixture, timer, heat lamp). Annual maintenance: $20-40 for bulb replacements. Over a 15-20 year gecko lifespan, this is a minor cost for significant health benefits.

content.text: Common Problems and Solutions:

rows: UVB too intense, or area too hot
Measure UVI (should be 1.0-2.0, not 3.0+), check basking temp (should be 82-85F max)
Add 6500K LED or brighter heat lamp for better color rendering
Add low-level UVB (1.0-2.0 UVI) to improve calcium metabolism and skin health
Replace fixture ballast or entire fixture if old (T8 fixtures degrade after 3-5 years)
UVB bulb still lights but gecko seems lethargic
Replace bulb even though it still produces visible light, UVB degrades faster than visible light
Add more foliage for shade, reduce to one light source, gecko should have choice to avoid light
